chapter.title: Installing and Configuring &app;
chapter.para: There are two ways of installing &app;: using a package manager or installing from source.

sect1.title: Requirements
sect1.para: Before downloading and installing &app;, check that your hardware and software meet the following requirements.

sect2.title: Hardware Requirements
sect2.para: One of the goals of &app; is to make it portable enough to install on small devices. As a result, the hardware requirements are minimal. &app; has even run on an ARM9 at 200 MHz with 64 MB of RAM! (It ran without video support in this case.) listitem.para: Video — &app; will run on anything from a raw frame buffer up to an OpenGL-supporting graphics card.

sect2.title: Software Requirements
sect2.para: The &appversion; release of &app; has been designed to run on UNIX/Linux variants, and has been run on most of the free ones. However, &app; has successfully run on Windows, Darwin (Mac OS X), Irix, Solaris, BeOs, OS/2, and Haiku. &app; has also run on the following 64-bit systems: PowerPC, Itanium, UltraSparc, and AMD64. For now, it is important to be sure that the following code, testing, and documentation dependencies are met before installing &app;. If you will be downloading &app; with a package manager, these dependencies may be solved by the package manager. Otherwise, you must first verify that each of these dependencies are installed on the target system.

sect1.title: Downloading &app;
sect1.para: There are two ways to download &app;: using a package manager or by downloading the source code and building it on your system. If possible, it is advisable to use a package manager to download &app;, as it will resolve dependencies for you. However, if you want the very latest features, or a &app; package is not available for your operating system, it is better to download the source code and build &app; locally.

sect2.title: Getting the Source
sect2.para: &app; is available as a release tarball, a development checkout, or a development snapshot.

sect3.title: Releases
sect3.para: The source can be acquired from a GNU FTP Mirror. The release version is intended to be stable, and is probably your best choice if the release took place recently. If you need features or fixes which were introduced after the release, consider a CVS checkout or the daily snapshot.
To download, select a mirror near you, then choose the gnash directory.

sect3.title: Repository
sect3.para: The latest development sources are available via anonymous CVS. This is recommended if you need features or bug fixes which were introduced after the last release. Look at the daily snapshot if you experience difficulty accessing the repository.

sect3.title: Snapshot
sect3.para: The daily development snapshot can be downloaded from http://www.gnashdev.org/dev_snapshots/. This is the best option if you need changes which were introduced after the last release of &app;, but are unable to download directly from the repository.
